# foundry command line client

A command line application designed to chat and share files.

## foundry machine interface

The foundry functional interface uses tools and tool_calls.

Only recent models provide tools interface, foundry should fall 
back to a no tools completion mode.

See the OpenAI API spec for more tool role details.

### read_time

### submit_file

### annotate_foundry

## foundry user interface

commands with no arguments may often prompt for a # index from
the items displayed

### /config

Toggle configuration flags.

Adjust settings to suit current preferences.

Default values are typically:

* 0 commitonstart : commit shared files on start : true
* 1 ansi : markdown ANSI rendering : true
* 2 slow : output at reading speed : true
* 3 verbose : emit debug information : true
* 4 broken : ansi background blocks : false
* 5 logging : log all output to file : true
* 6 resetcounters : at reset zero all counters : true

### /share

Share a file or folder with optional tag.

Files are added to the share list used by the /push /commit command.

### /drop

Drop all files currently shared

### /push /commit

Refresh shared files. 

Detects changes or deletions and updates the chat history.

Posts new versions of file content if modified.

### /reset

Clear all shared files and conversation history.

### /history

List a summary of recent conversation entries. 

Provides a quick overview of chat history.

### /cd

Change the working directory. 

User can navigate to a desired directory for file operations.

### /dir

List the contents of the current working directory. 

Helps user view available files and folders to share.


### /model

Select an AI model.

User can choose a model by name or index from the accounts available.

### /counters

List the internal application counters.

### /tag

Describe all tags in use.

Displays tag name, count of shares tagged and description.

### /account

Display current account information.

### /save [name]

Save the current conversation history. 

Creates a snapshot file of the conversation.

The default name is currently .roa-save-HEX32_TIME.json

### /load

Load a saved conversation history snapshot.

User can specify a save index or file name to restore previous chats.


### /time

Display the current system time. 

Helps user verify system status.

### /help

If you are reading this file, it may be due to the use of this command.

If you still need help visit the project page.

Below are several observations after reviewing the Foundry.js source code. Note that I did not run the code, so some comments are based solely on static review:

1. General Observations

â€¢ The code is organized as a monolithic script with many global variables (for example, roha, rohaHistory, modelList, etc.). In a longâ€term project you might want to refactor parts into separate modules for clarity and maintainability.

â€¢ The use of raw terminal I/O (via Deno.stdin.setRaw(true)) appears to be handled with a tryâ€¦finally block in prompt2, which is good. However, ensure that every possible error path (including asynchronous exceptions) correctly resets raw mode.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
2. Specific Functional Sections and Potential Issues

Prompt Handling (prompt2 function):
â€ƒâ€“ The function sets raw mode and reads bytes. The finally clause resets raw mode.
â€ƒâ€“ There is a branch for when the escape (0x1b) byte is encountered. In that branch, if the value length equals 1 the code calls Deno.exit(0) immediately. This abrupt termination might bypass any cleanup not covered by finallyâ€”double-check that this is acceptable.
â€ƒâ€“ The handling of escape sequences (when value length equals 3) is very specific (checks for 0xf4 and 0x50). Confirm that these assumptions are accurate for all platforms you intend to support.

File and Share Handling:
â€ƒâ€“ In shareFile, the code distinguishes between text files and binary files based solely on file extension. This works in many cases, but be aware that the list of text extensions might need updates as you add more file types.
â€ƒâ€“ The commitShares function uses Deno.stat; if a file has been removed, the error is caught and its path is added to removedPaths. This seems fine, but you might want to log such removals more prominently.

Command Processing (callCommand function):
â€ƒâ€“ The switch statement handles numerous commands. Most commands catch errors and print error messages via echo, which is helpful.
â€ƒâ€“ When the command is not recognized, the function returns false. It may be useful to also log this or provide additional guidance to the user.

Relay and Tool Calling:
â€ƒâ€“ The relay() function recursively calls itself after processing tool calls. Make sure that the recursion terminates as expected when no further tool calls are returned; an inadvertent design might cause infinite recursion if the model repeatedly sends tool call instructions.
â€ƒâ€“ Some merging of messages happens in squashMessages. The function concatenates system and nonâ€‘system messages separately but be sure that the resulting history still meets your modelâ€™s expected format.
â€ƒâ€“ Every time a tool call is processed, rohaCalls is incremented. Although this works in a singleâ€‘threaded environment, ensure that the counter remains reliable over long sessions if scaling out.

Global State:
â€ƒâ€“ Various globals (roha, rohaHistory, modelList, etc.) are mutated. A potential improvement is ensuring that state is encapsulated so unit tests can validate individual blocks.
